review_title: An organization fueled by passionate and dedicated employees

pros: As soon as I started working here it became obvious just how much the employees from top to bottom truly care about the mission of the organization and serving the community. cons: Being a non-profit the salaries are capped on the lower paying end due to funding/budget but in my opinion the benefits, vacation/sick time, and environment help to balance that out.  Technology can be limited but they have made some recent strides in this area by introducing new software programs and applications.

pros:
-You get very attached to the kids and their families
-The work is rewarding.  Seeing how much progress the children make---partially because of our help--keeps you going!
-High level of independence/autonomy.
-Good co-workers, although I don't get to see them often and by the time you begin to get to know them, the turnover is so frequent that they leave!
cons:
-The pay is WAY too low for what is required of this position. When you REQUIRE a college degree to get hired for a job, COMPENSATE ACCORDINGLY. Providers are required to work long sessions (sometimes with challenging kiddos who have a lot of trouble paying attention for 2-2.5 hours, scream, kick, hit, throw things), do a TON of ridiculous and often unnecessary paperwork, and basically need to "prove" what we do every minute of the day...all for $15-$17 an hour. This position should pay at LEAST $40k a year for what is involved.

-The position involves a lot of travel. You're told this going into it, but it can be challenging...especially in the winter. 

-INSANE amount of employee turnover. I've never seen anything like it before, actually. It's probably because we never get raises (just quarterly bonuses, which are pretty low) and people have to move on because they can't afford to pay their bills. 

-Everything is about meeting productivity/billing each week, but scheduling is horrible--leaving providers with tons of open times--and we are frequently required to find our own appointments to fill in the gaps so that we don't get spoken to for not making productivity. 

-They compensate you a measly $25 a year for toys. You are expected to provide all your own toys (and a LOT of them--our car trunks are FULL). The educational toys can be pretty expensive, too. This can add up very quickly. I've spent at least a $200-$300 on toys in just the past year I've been here. $25 is laughable.
